citation.article-title: Leifsonia gen. nov., a genus for 2,4-diaminobutyric acid-containing actinomycetes to accommodate Corynebacterium aquaticum Leifson 1962 and Clavibacter xyli subsp. cynodontis Davis et al. 1984
citation.source: The Journal of General and Applied Microbiology

p.s: Description of Leifsonia shinshuensis sp. nov.

Leifsonia shinshuensis (shin.shu.en'sis. N. L. adj. shinshuensis referring to Shinshu, which is the old name of Nagano Prefecture, Japan [the source of soil sample from which the type strain was isolated])
Cells are Gram-positive, obligatory aerobic, and nonspore forming rods (generally 0.3 to 0.4 by 2.5 to 3.0 μm in a 2-day culture).
Colonies on R agar are glossy, smooth, and entire.
White colonies of a 2-day-culture turn to pale brown in old culture at 30°C.
Acid is produced from fructose, glycerol, and inulin, but not from D-xylose, maltose, mannose, L-rhamnose, glucose, galactose, mannitol, melibiose, salicin, sucrose, D-trehalose, or amygdalin.
Lactate, pyruvate, fumarate, malate, formate, succinate, and propionate are assimilated, but citrate and n-butyrate are not.
Starch is hydrolyzed but DNA is not.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite.
The predominant menaquinones are MK-11 and MK-12.
The G+C content of DNA is 71 mol%.
The type strain of L. shinshuensis is DB102 (JCM 10591).
The source of isolation is soil.
